38782010.review:
Before the Early Access 2.0 release I would have recommended this game all day, up/down, left/right, etc. 

Early Access 2.0 changed the whole feel of the game. The core mechanics are the same with some added "bonuses".
Hit a ball into tiles in 360 degrees and try to create combos and avoid traps/hazards such as portals and time decreasing tiles.

The cons(basicly everything that was added/changed in 2.0)
Bariers around tiles that will deflect and cancel a combo shot. On paper this sounds like it would add to the fun of the game but it's really just a huge pain and a burden on the gameplay.
Pulsating color pallet. The colors move to the music. Also sounds like it would be good for the game, but it's distracting. 
The colors are also the same(very similar) as the ball that you are trying to keep your eye on so you can lose it while it's sliding around the wall, then it just comes right back at you.
The Lanes that pull the ball up to you in slow motion are now on a charge. meh. If this was the only thing that changed in 2.0 I wouldn't complain, but still kinda crappy.

The game before 2.0 was amazing and where I put my ~30 hours in. I played for several hours at a time taking a break sweating and panting, going for a gatorade, then going right back. After the update, I have played about 20 minutes and uninstalled.

The original had a Tron-type feel to it. Simple but very difficult. This just feels like a modernized version of 'futuristic', not the 80's/90's feel of futuristic. Some people like it. Give the demo a try, but the game pre-2.0 was 10000x's better.

38186061.review:
Racket: NX is basically tennis meets breakout. This game does a lot of things right and is just a fun, super polished experience. The positional audio is fantastic, and the graphics are very well done. The gameplay seems simple at first but actually contains a bit of strategy in terms of where you want to hit the ball to avoid 'downers', whether you want to try a slam which will roll along the edge or just a regular bounce to build up your 'freeze' move, etc. This seems like a title with a high skill ceiling.

I generally like my VR experiences short, in the half hour to hour range, so games like this that I can jump in, play a few rounds then quit are great.

Workout wise, I'd say it's low impact - you can work up a sweat, but it doesn't require you to move around much (you can stay in the middle more or less), and it's not as frantic as Audio Shield can be. It also only requires one hand.

36402359.review:
Really good hit the ball game, quite challenging in single player, the first stage is  easy enough, but from then on things get tricky.  Multiplayer is great fun, although the rematch button doesn't seem to work correctly atm.

Playing this on the RIft but with 3 sensors, there's a lot of turning around so if you're on 2 sensors you might run into issues, but running 3 sensors the tracking's great of course.

Advisable to have some room when playing this, particuarly when swinning arm, i've hit the table a couple of times, plus a chair!  Top tip, stick a couple of cushions on top of the table, that way if you do hit the table then you're at leat not doing any damage.

So what do you do in this? Basically you hit a ball against a 360 degree wall whilst trying to hit the right coloured spaces, your health goes down over time unless you hit health things, it can also go down if you hit little alien things, that's after 2 levels,

 I'm sure there's more stuff later but that's as far as i've got so far.  The walls arent always flat either, which can make it tricky to get some shots.  There's more to it than that though as your paddle thing can get power ups, also the ball can travell along the wall aswell if hit hard enough.

The only thing I don't like about it is the option to pull the ball near you with a beam,  I can understand why it's in there but I still don't really like that feature, not a big deal but wish it wasn't in there.

Love the menu for settings with dials to adjust sound etc, looks really nice and shows how much attention has gone into things.

Great VR title highly reccoment it.

36350286.review:
I initially thought this might be a fun little time waster, but now I think this is going to get an old, fat guy into better shape.

I've always enjoyed tennis, both watching and playing on my Xbox, but was never able to play in real life because I'm fat and have shitty knees and joints.  I used to occasionally play racquetball at the gym, but worsening joints, arthritis, bad feet, etc., etc. had me stop that a while ago.  I missed it.

So, imagine how happy I was to find that this game simulates the feel of racket sports without the jarring body motion of trying to run back and forth on a court, turning on a dime.  You still get body motion since the ball and targets move all around you, but it's contained within the couple yards of your play space so it's never too far out of your reach.

I picked this up on a sale for $12, but I would be happy if I had paid the full $20, I think.

Since it is early access (as of the time of this writing), there are things that could be improved and added upon, but it's pretty solid at the moment (full disclosure, I spent nearly all my time in "Zen Mode" with no timer, penalties, or anything else.  Just targets and fun.) 

A couple of things that *I* think could be improved:
Ball control seems a bit loose, but that could be my skill level and lack of stamina
I would love to see the ability to slow down the action in Zen mode.  If I could open the pause menu and decrease the ball speed by 10%-50%, that would be great!  It would allow for a much more "zen" experience for the old people who don't move as fast as we used to (it would also make for an easy accessibility feature)
Give the user a glass dome and put the dome in some fantastic locations (under the ocean with fish and stuff, on an alien planet in town square, center court WImbledon, etc.)
Add in a skills mode that forces the user to hit targets with only a forehand, or only a backhand, or only left-handed, etc.  These modes could also be used as game modifiers in multiplayer and solo games by adding pickups that occasionally spawn around the arena (smaller targets so some skill is required to hit them)

All in all, I think this game will be a good step towards turning an old, fat guy into an old, less-fat guy because it's fun, engaging, active, and has that all-important feel of "just one more level".  My hands, arms, and shoulders are a bit sore from my session last night, but I'm still looking forward too playing some more tonight!

I have only played 12 minutes of this game so far but everything about it is just stunning and huge fun. I just had to stop because I am exhausted and realise how much exercise I need. 

We all have that one sweaty friend, the one who tried Google Earth VR for 5 minutes then hands the HMD back dripping wet. The guy we bought that waterproof face cushion for. Do not let that guy play this game - he will have it soaked through to the electronics before the tutorial is over. 

If you have a tendency to walk through the chaperone boundaries in games, or have friends who think the boundary is an optional boundary, then do not get this game. You wil be swinging your arms fast! Get Vive wand protectors and coat all your walls in rubber before playing this. 

The aesthetics of the game are perfect - quite Tron like without being too basic. Everything is running so smoothly (currently running on an i7-4770 and GTX1080 with Steam supersampling set to 2)

I can't wait for my heart to calm down so I can play some more.

36159394.review:
My goodness, this is a workout for all kinds of wrist, arm and shoulder muscles!

Very energetic game. Works perfectly on the HTC Vive with a Gigabyte ATI Radeon RX480 video card.

Between this and Zen's Pinball FX2 VR, I don't think any other VR games are needed. 
This one is certainly worth full price. 

Try the demo, but beware, it gets a lot more tiring in the real game. 
Play the demo for a good while, until you are sure your arm can stand 
up to the level of workout it's going to get in the real game!
I can't imagine how tiring multiplayer must be...

After the initial exhausting attempts to get past the first few solo levels, I decided to 
take a break and read the guide. Thankfully, it explains about trying to not hit the 
skulls so as to avoid draining energy. I was doing just the opposite. Meh! Live and learn.

While reading the guides, I noticed a typo on one of the later pages of the 
guide (two letters reversed near the end of a sentence, sorry I forget which
word it was, something to do with sound perhaps).

I love the ingenious game mechanic of slicing the ball. It's still quite tricky to do
it reliably. I don't understand how, but my aim is gradually improving.
I still have to remember to carefully watch the chaperone bounds,
to avoid bumping the wall, though, especially when I get close to 
the end of the level and time is running out. Crazy fun!

For relaxing and warming up, the Zen mode is very lovely.

The Zen mode is also helpful to introduce the various target elements.
Insanely hard to hit those moving hezagon snakes, tricky creatures!

Perhaps having various metallic texture sounds for the shiny metallic 
hexagons,  and glass sounds for the transparent sections, could  be interesting, rather than 
just having a single bounce sound irrespective of the surface. Just listening to the sound of
the plasma orb as it goes behind you can be good practice for locating it in the game.

In Zen mode, perhaps "floating sections" could appear between the wall and
the player, turning the game into a kind of puzzle with different levels?

I'm not terribly keen on the "floor dropping away" effect at the end of the solo mode.
It'd be great to be able to disable this and have something less vertigo-inducing,
maybe just having some outside sunlight coming in from the windows as you
attempt to unwind the headset cable, while keeping the floor in place.

The "wound cable" graphic on the floor is a great idea. It's great to be able to
unwind the cable without needing to peek out of the headset.

Thanks for a great game.

35928443.review:
Excellent game so far.  Atmosphere is good, music is good, the feel of the ball is good.  If this is an indicator of where the game is going, it may end up being one of the top games a VR set owner needs to get.

It may take a while to get good at it, but for the same kinds of reasons it takes a while to get good at actual raquetball.  Game mechanics here seem to serve mainly to guide your natural hand-eye coordination, without ever really getting in the way.

Some things that I would think might be good in the final are options to increase game speed, maybe a way to have several flying balls you can hit instead of just one (Arkanoid comes to mind), maybe more variation in the distance between the walls and the player.

Anyway, this is early access, so the game isn't loaded with options.  But the game mechanics are superb, and the game is well-primed to handle any new options brilliantly.

Hitting the ball is satisfying and it feels like it goes where it should. The game looks great, and has a clean UI and menus. What I don't care for however is the execution (not the idea) of the energy system. Most of the times where I find myself able to line up a bunch of energy I'm already at 100%. I really don't like how the skulls (negative energy) are placed in areas were goals arn't. I don't feel I should have to worry about hitting bad spots while just repositioning the ball. I feel empty areas should be... welll empty. I feel like I'm hitting more plus signs that skulls but I just hit the skulls at bad times. If I get low on energy, I find myself dying just trying to reposition the ball because it hits some random skull I didn't even see. That is another thing. FoV is pretty low in VR, and this is the kind of game where that REALLY hurts you. The game also requires you to spin a lot which makes the cord wrap around my legs. The cord combined with FoV issues really exacerbate the problem I have with skulls being placed in open random areas because the ball often strikes them when I'm trying to untangle myself or reposition the ball by using open walls that I don't have a good visual on. In other words... it feels very bad to lose. It feels like I got unlucky rather than me messing up.

My proposal would be to not have skulls in open areas and to increase the power of the pull back mechanic that uses energy. It would make it a better tool for repositioning the ball, and it would allow you to pull it away from skulls. 

I'm sorry if my thoughts seem a bit scattered, but I'd like to list more positives. The portals are a great mechanic for repositioning which is the area I think the game needs the most work. I would like to have a better tell of where the balls are comming out though. Maybe the exit portal could light up so you can find it faster while turning around (this would help alleviate FoV visiability issues). Another great thing is the rolling mechanic. I absolutely love it, and it adds a whole layer of depth to the game. It is very creative. I think it can be improved though. Currently, if I hit the ball medium hard it has just as much speed as if I did if I hit it extremely hard. I'd like to see the ball's cap for speed raised. I want to be able to take a risk by hitting the ball very hard. I'm not sure if this is a technological limitation or an intentional limitation, but it feels jarring to me that there isn't a different between hitting the ball twice as hard once it reaches a certain point.

I'd like to thank the devs for working on a game like this for VR. This is the perfect kind of game for VR as it is now. 

It is something that could only be done in VR.

It takes a familiar feel of real life sports and takes the fantasy to the next level.

It isn't overly ambitious for its medium (too many games feel like tech demos rather than games because they try to make games that are heavily hindered by VRs limitations and end up feeling incomplete)


The VR scene would be far far better if more developers had the vision of Racket NX rather than trying to copy normal AAA titles in ways that make games feel more like the husk of something else. I look forward to see the develpment progress in this game more than most, and I'd love to see it suceed so more VR developers will understand what makes for a good VR game.

30632527.review:
For a VR game based on a simple premise, I was afraid Racket:NX won't deliver in the long run like the countless 'A class' VR games I possess that either fall short or has promised to provide out of EA. Like many of you hesitant to buy a true esport game due to EA as well as spending money on something with low replayability value thus cringing your money short.

Truth be told, at the beginning, I almost believed that was true but even in EA one, Racket:NX shines its magnificent primier of what TRUE ESPORTS can do for you. True Esports is one without seating, where your arena is room scale and you sweat and grind for glory, PHYSICALLY. (On  the one hand, being a fan of esports, I cringe the day MOBAs die off being replaced by VR competitive sports but boy am I glad VR took a healthy active turn for the better)

Racket NX feels bland at first and as though the racket, ball, and shiny glowy things are just for show and you keep hitting it like its a toy. Your shots are going wide, your wondering whether your controller is fucked or development was stupid. Then, you start noticing sounds coming from different locations and your headphones actually can produce surround quality effects. You realise the ball itself emits a sound and so do the wormholes to indicate where the ball is coming from. After you score some finished sets, you begin to realise you are actually getting better not through mental training but literally both mental and physical training. The ball no longer feels like a toy, it becomes heavy and every location it is in VR IS EXTREMELY VITAL INFORMATION.

Your shots start being accurate for once and you realize what happens when you hit the ball too early or too late because even that minute detail...MATTERS. Suddenly you got angry and saw a confident shot, you BLAM the ball in the best position and you realize the white smash speed trail that runs across the wall gaining you multiple hits. Before long, the smash starts becoming a spin. Yes...racket NX turned Tennis, Table, Tennis, Squash and Badminton sideways and puked on all of them by giving players the ability to SPIN!! 

Summary:

Seeing a curving smashed ball clearing a score plate finishing a set? Priceless. What I'm trying to get at is the game's ability to play with physical elements of your body, essentially 'upgrading' your character manually...through YOU, physically, like natural sports. You actually progress through the game by actually being better, physically, no need for ultimates, abilities or mana, your stamina IS YOUR MANA. The cream on top for an esport EA 1? Multiplayer sets! where they essentially took the table tennis, squash doubles play and slam it in this high action impact sports but unlike any sport (since there is no dome arena except in cycling), you can 'snooker' your enemy by giving him a hard ball in the cleared section, which means you need to learn reverse racketing as well.

There are many things that you will learn to do while playing this game, and you will never stop learning based on the game's ability to instill natural guides, that is your senses, into every playmaker move you make and that answers its replayability value. The game will make you learn more, its only natural and you will improve no matter how bad you are, that is another reason why I recommend this game as its progression is based on you and it will show you how naturally, you will know how you improve because the reward is instant the moment you feel the haptic feedback as the slow mo edge of your racket swings into vision and that aced smash ball zoning into that score plate breaking the glass of the dome, finishing the set.

Good luck to you all racketeers

10/10 would have a heart attack again flinging my touch into space for that sweet shot

30284195.review:
There's a lot to like about Racket:NX.  The graphics are outstanding, the mechanics and physics of hitting the ball are superior to other games I've played.  It's a lot of fun and gets the blood pumping.  

Unfortunately there are more things that I disliked about the game than things I did.  For starters, there's almost nothing that tells you what you need to do to play.  I know, I know. Hit ball with racket, right?  Except there are the times and how fast you hit the ball determines a lot of things.  The learning curve is steep, and it took playing through a few times to understand what I was even supposed to be doing.  

Then there's the portals.  The devs seem to REALLY love those portals.  Unfortunately they destroy the flow of the game play.  "Oh here! You have to hit this tile.  Let me surround it with portals that spit the ball back out from another location!"  As the difficulty increases, the game uses the portals to an absurd degree.  Which, maybe some people like, but it leads to the next issue I have.

The game favors very slow accurate shots rather than allowing you to really get the ball going around the court.  Because of the aforementioned portals, it becomes nearly impossible later in the game to play fast.  Instead, hitting with any sort of accuracy to avoid the portals means taking single, slow shots, which becomes boring.  I get that the portals are meant to make the game more challenging, but instead they just make it more frustrating by forcing you to play a specific way.  

I'm not sure whether to recommend this or not.  I'm just not sure it's worth $20 at this point.  I know it's early access, but honestly I think I'd recommend waiting until they've made some changes.

***Update to Review***

Because of the passion with which the Devs, who reached out to me after I posted my review, and the Racket:NX community have shown, I continued playing and have 12 hours of gameplay in at this point.  One of the developers suggested that it would take 12 to 18 hours just to master the basics.  Unfortunately, further time playing hasn't changed my mind. And, in fact, only reinforces my belief that the learning curve and increase in difficulty are simply too steep for the majority of players.  While I enjoy a challenge and find many aspects of this game enjoyable, I believe the 12-18 hours required to simply pick up the basics is more than most casual players will want to invest.  I think this game absolutely will appeal to those who want to spend 4-5 hours a day practicing to get to the necessary skill level, but for someone like me who just wants to play a game a couple of times a day as a way to break up my work, it's simply frustrating. As it is an Early Access game, I'll check in with it periodically to see if any changes have been made.

***Second Update***

I'm changing my recommendation from No to Yes because of the most recent update which improved the physics and, more importantly, added a Zen mode which allows new players to practice without the timer. 29978902.review:
Fracture on Arcade Saga is a fan favorite at my place. This looked similar so I picked it up and I enjoy this much more than I thought I would. It's more challenging than I thought, but after a few attempts I was finding it more and more rewarding. While Fracture has an arcade feel to it, Racket is a bit more polished with a modern tech feel. One thing I like about Racket is the need for only one controller. I find it useful to keep my free hand on the cable behind me in order to keep my bearings.

Once you get down the basics, you'll notice that you can apply a good amount of spin on the ball for some really cool curve shots or shots that travel along the walls hitting multiple tiles. There's an announcer present to keep you informed and to compliment you on exceptional shots. 360 degree sound is your friend in this game. Listening can tell you which direction to go when you can't see your target.

So I decided to go into multiplayer. That's where the magic happens. SO fun! You're competing against someone who looks like a bot. Wave hello! You take turns hitting the same ball. It changes color when it's your turn to hit it. It almost has a co-op sort of feel to it. I was only able to play one game, so please add to the player pool. :) 

Be extra cautious of your boundaries. I had a couple of collisions and I play in a good size area.

tl;dr: Very polished, high tech racket sports game that rewards skillful play. Very fun multiplayer. A solid buy for anyone looking for a game to get their body moving.

29877751.review:
I feel like VR has a lot of people writing their first Steam review. Well it's my turn now.
As VR users know, most content right now relies on the "WOW!" factor to be appealing, and games that are still actually fun once the VR magic fades are few and far in between. Racket: Nx is one of the only VR games I played (my VR collection has ~40 games) that is genuinely fun.

IMO, this is largely due to the "power shot" mechanics. By hitting the ball hard, it is possible to hit many tiles in a line, while the direction of that line depends on the shot's angle and spin. The concept is simple, but being able to hit hard while controlling both aim and spin requires a lot of practice. Very few VR games require any skill from the player, but this element of skill/mastery is what makes most games fun: sports, FPS, RTS, they all get more fun as you play and become better at them.

However, because of that, it might not suit everyone's taste. Fortunately there's a demo, so you can see exactly what the game is like. You get more game modes (including multiplayer) in the full game, but you won't need that to see whether you like the game or not.

Definitely do try out the demo, this game is what I'm expecting from VR in the next few years.

的を正確に狙い撃つ慎重さと、パワーショットで連続ヒットをとる大胆さ、それらを使い分けて戦略的に立ち回らないとマルチでの勝利だけでなくソロモードのクリアもままならない、シンプルながらなかなか奥深いテニス/スカッシュ+ブロック崩し+ピンボール風VRスポーツゲームです。

ゲーム開始直後は適当に打っても的を連続ヒットできて気持ちいいです。ですが、手数が進むと狙う的が減少し、当てると逆に減点となる的などのお邪魔要素が出現して、難易度があがります。何発撃っても狙った的にいかない時もあり、正直最初は「思ったより爽快感がないな」と感じました。しかし、打ったボールの挙動は感覚的に非常に納得のいくよう作られており、Viveコンはご存知の通り正確にラケットの振る速度や角度をVR空間に反映してくれるため、リアルのスポーツと同様に、自身の身体感覚を研ぎ澄ましていくことがそのまま結果となって帰ってきます。いろんなモードで試行錯誤してコツをつかみ、テクニックを開発し、汗でHMDを曇らせながら高難度のソロステージをクリアしマルチプレイで対戦相手を打ち負かすのは、やはり爽快の一言です。

日本の家屋事情だとPVを見てこのゲームを敬遠しちゃうかもしれませんが、基本的にルームスケールの中心を維持するプレイになるので、案外大丈夫です。私は2m×2mがギリギリの部屋でのプレイですが、フローリングの床の中心に30cm×30cmのタイルマットを敷いてその上に少なくとも片足がのるプレイを意識したところ、手を振り回して家具をたたくなどの心配はまったくありませんでした。（この方法、ほかのゲームでも有効なので結構オススメ）

アーリーアクセス2になり、8つのソロミッション、エンドレスのアーケード2種、1vs1のマルチプレイを遊べます。ソロだけでも特に後半の難易度は高く結構遊べますが、やはりマルチが楽しいですね。正式リリースまで段階的なバージョンアップや要素追加のロードマップが提示されていますが、ちょっと開発が遅れ気味のようで残念です。

それでも現時点での完成度は高く、挙動やSE、グラフィックやUIなど、総じてクオリティの高いゲームだと思います。オススメ！

29638255.review:
Ich bin hingerissen und ordentlich ins Schwitzen geraten bei meinen ersten Paar runden in Racket: NX. Vor allem beeindruckt mich die Präzision der Schlagphysik. Dem Ball ordentlich einen zu pfeffern und dabei anzuschneiden ist Kernelement des Spiels. Dadurch zieht der Ball nicht nur eine Kurve in die erwartete Richtung. Wenn genug Power hinter dem Schlag steckt, läuft der Ball nach dem Auftreffen auf der Wand eine Bahn über mehrere benachbarte Hexfelder der Wand. Falls es sich um aktive Felder handelt, löst man diese damit aus, sammelt die entsprechenden Punkte mit einem Schlag.

Ich hoffe, das Spiel bekommt noch einen 2-Player Modus im Stile der Tron-Diskus-Arena. Es ist schon sehr nah dran. Und wer weiß, wie lange wir noch auf "Project Arena" warten müssen.

Good job, dudes! :)
Looking forward to more waves, maybe different room geometries and more specials.

29634173.review:
Racket:Nx feels like a sport that would be popular in the tron universe. It is an tennis like game that puts you in an arena with glowing hexagons you need to hit with a crazy, kinetic, alternate gravity ball. For a VR early access title, it is already super polished. The ball and racket physics feel pretty much perfect (I am not good enough at the game yet to verify this accuratley, but it feels fair for the most part) and the graphics are actually quite nice! It is a pretty simple game, but as polished as job simulator.

Play the demo. It show you everything you need to know about the game and probably could be a pretty good tool for showing others VR all on its own. But the full game has many more tricks up its sleeve, and multiplayer if you are into that kind of thing. 

FYI RIFT OWNERS: It works if you have the touch and a 360 setup. It will require a bit of room to play this thing, so make as much space as you can!

29633370.review: Really good game. I hope to find more multiplayer matches.

29630536.review:
Ce jeu est sans doute le meilleur jeu de sport que j'ai pu tester en VR.

Le jeu est un mélange de squash et de casse-brique avec une ambiance futuriste.

On a un mode solo arcade infini, ou la difficulté augmente progressivement.
Un autre mode solo ou on choisit une série de tableaux qui ont été créer spécialement a la main, le but étant de finir tout les niveaux avec le plus gros score, et de comparer son score sur ces tableaux en ligne.

Ensuite on a le mode multijoueur!

Ce jeu propose un gameplay endiablé sur 360°
On peu commencer lentement pour apprendre a bien visé.
Puis dès que l'on est a l'aise on peu envoyé des grosses patates avec des effets sur la sphère, c'est génial et jouissif.

Le jeu a les prémices aussi de power ups! Dans la prochaine mise a jour ils seront présent. Hâte de voir de quoi il en retourne!

Techniquement c'est la claque, ambiance futuriste, on est dans une sphère constitué d'hexagones de toute beauté. Dans les options on peu pousser le super sampling jusqu?à 2,5 et mettre de l'anti aliasing par dessus, c'est beau, c'est fun, c'est propre, c'est immersif, c'est Racket NX!

Je le recommande vivement!

29619318.review: (Edit: I'm obsessed with this game now) WOW! this game is one hell of a fun workout... the 3d sound is f**king incredible, its something i have not experienced at this level of accuracy yet in VR.. its faciniating how well this works you can hear EXACTLY where the ball is coming from 360 degrees around you, its like you are truly there in that arena... this is a great challenge and a heck of a blast.. the amount of precise control you have over the ball is amazing, the graphics.. everything... these devs are clearly very talented. i was not expecting this to be so awesome.. this is an extremely polished game and he multiplayer is so much  fun.. there's a good amount of people playing too so you're not waiting more than 2 minutes to find a game. hitting that ball is so incredibly satisfying and if you screw up and dont keep up, you will get closer and closer to loosing, You can recover by hitting the point squares all around you which are constantly changing... and oh is it ever satisfying... this is one of the most polished experiences available right now for the vive. im blown away by this game, Its just awesome fun and i very highly recommend it.

29617434.review:
This game is absolutely awesome if I may say so! This is like a true sport in VR, and with esport features coming I hope there will be plenty of players, and an active and competitive community. Not all want to play competitively of course, and the game is really fun, I'd say most people who enjoy racket sports to some degree will enjoy this, or if you played other similar games. 

The physics are incredible, you have extreme control over the ball. You can swirve the ball and apply spin like in real life, so it feel very realistic and convincing. This is a really great concept and so far it's really well executed. 

I have played this a lot, and it is my favorite VR game at the moment. That is because I love sport games, and this is like really long membership in a virtual sports club, and for only a small price I have all the facilities needed to practice and play other people at any time I want. I love playing sports and competition in real life, and this adds a very covinient extra option.

I play on the Rift, and the tracking for high speed movements is bad, but I can still play and is quite competitive on the leaderboards, where I've been in the top 10 most of the time. Other than that it works, and it's highly recommended even if you have a Rift, just know that it's not officially supported so we are just lucky that there isn't any issues.

29617168.review:
I've been waiting for Racket NX for ages since the demo came out.  If you also enjoyed the demo then you'll be glad to hear that nothing fundamental has changed now that it has entered Early Access.

The physics feel natural and everything runs smoothly.  I've noticed one bug when trying to select a rematch in multiplayer but other than that the game's very well put together, this isn't an Early Access game that has only been in development for a couple of weeks and I'd be happy if this were the finished product.

The graphics are nicely done and you get in-game options to increase anti-aliasing and supersampling.  I tried upping the SS but I felt the improvements weren't that noticeable (unlike a game like Raw Data where SS really makes a difference) and I thought it introduced a bit of lag (Nvidia 970).  I may have been imagining the lag but for this type of game where you need fast reactions it's not worth it just so that the already clear, polished graphics look a little bit prettier.

I've had my Vive since June/July and this is the first and only game I've played against others in multiplayer!  It's a lot of fun (who'd have thought) and I didn't experience any lag or choppiness.

All in all a great game and straight into my top 3 VR games (to be honest the demo already was :) .

The game also has (equally nicely done) settings that can be used to really ramp up the graphics quality (AA and supersampling), even though it looks really good compared to some other games even at default settings. Highly recommended!

类似的运动VR游戏玩过不少了，这游戏最出彩的是画质，充满了高科技的质感，画面质感真是晶莹剔透，看得我都想咬一口球拍。
